ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: MetaTrial Visit ID
Notes: System variable: unique code for each type of visit -use to merge files

ElementDescription: Visit type

Does the subject have beliefs that you know are not true? For example, insisting that people are trying to harm him/her or steal from him/her? Has he/she said that family members are not who they say they are or that the house is not their home?
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section B. Hallucinations; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions A1-10; 9 = N.A. Not Applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject believe that he/she is in danger- that others are planning to hurt him/her?

Does subject believe
that others are stealing from him/her?
Does subject believe that his/her spouse is having an affair?

Does subject believe
that unwelcome guests are living in his/her house?
Does subject believe that his/her spouse or others are not who they claim to be?

Does subject believe
that his/her house is not his/her home?
Does subject believe that family members plan to abandon him/her?
Does subject believe that television or magazine figures are actually present in the how? (Does he/she try to talk or interact with them?)
Does subject believe any other unusual things that I haven't asked about?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Does the subject have hallucinations such as false visions or voices? Does he/she seem to see, hear or experience things that are not present? By this question we do not mean just mistaken beliefs such as stating that someone who had dies is still alive; rather we are asking if the subject actually has abnormal experiences of sounds or visions.
Notes: 0 = No proceed to section C. Agitation/Aggr; 1 = Yes proceed to subquestions 1-8; 9 = N.A. Not Applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject describe hearing voices or act as if he/she hears voices?
Does subject talk to people who are not there?

Does subject
describe seeing things not seen by others or behave as if he/she is seeing things not seen by others (people, animals, lights, etc.)?
Does subject report smelling odors not smelled by others?

Does subject
describe feeling things on his/her skin or otherwise appear to be feeling things crawling or touching him/her?
Does subject describe tastes that are without any known cause?
Does subject describe any other unusual sensory experiences?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Agitation/Aggression
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section D. Depression/Dys; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions 1-9; 9 = N.A. Not Applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject get upset with those trying to care for him/her or resist activities such as bathing or changing clothes?
Is subject stubborn, having to have things his/her way?
Is subject uncooperative, resistive to help from others?
Does subject have any other behaviors that make him/her hard to handle?
Does subject shout or curse angrily?
Does subject slam doors, kick furniture, throw things?
Does subject attempt to hurt or hit others?
Does subject have any other aggressive or agitated behaviors?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Depression/Dysphoria
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section E. Anxiety; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions 1-9; 9 = N.A. Not Applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject have periods of tearfulness or sobbing that seem to indicate sadness?

Does subject say or
act as if he/she is sad or in low spirits?
Does subject put him/herself down or say that he/she feels like a failure?

Does subject say
that he/she is a bad person or deserves to be punished?
Does subject seem very discouraged or say that he/she has no future?

Does subject say
he/she is a burden to the family or that the family would be better off without him/her?
Does subject express a wish for death or talk about killing him/herself?

Does subject show
any other signs of depression or sadness?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Anxiety
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section F. Elation/Euphor; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions E1-8; 9 = N.A. Not Applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject say that he/she is worried about planned events?

Does subject have
periods of feeling shaky, unable to relax, or feeling excessively tense?
Does subject have periods of (or complain of) shortness of breath, gasping, or sighing for no apparent reason other than nervousness?

Does subject
complain of butterflies in his/her stomach, or of racing or pounding of the heart in association with nervousness?
Does subject avoid certain places or situations that make him/her more nervous such as riding in the car, meting with friends, or being in crowds?

Does subject
become nervous or upset when seperated from you (or his/her caregiver)? [Does he/she cling to you to keep from being seperated?]
Does subject show any other signs of anxiety?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Elation/Euphoria
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section F. Elation/Euphor; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions E1-8; 9 = N.A. Not Applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject appear to feel too good or to be too happy, different from his/her usual self?

Does subject find
humor and laugh at things that others do not find funny?
Does subject seem to have a childish sense of humor with a tendency to giggle or laugh inappropriately (such as when something unfortunate happens to others)?

Does subject tell
jokes or make remarks that have little humor for others but seem funny to him/her?
Does he/she play childish pranks such as pinching or playing keep away for the fun of it?

Does subject talk big
or claim to have more abilities or wealth than is true?
Does subject show any other signs of signs of feeling too good or being too happy?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Apathy/Indifference
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section H. Disinhibition; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions 1-9; 9 = N.A. Not Applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject seem less spontaneous and less active than usual?
Is subject less likely to initiate a conversation?
Is subject less affectionate or lacking in emotions when compared to his/her usual self?
Does subject contribute less to houshold chores?
Does subject seem less interested in the activities and plans of others?
Has subject lost interest in friends and family members?
Is subject less enthusiastic about his/her usual interists?
Does subject show any other signs that he/she doesn't care about doing new things?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Disinhibition
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section I. Irritability/L; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions 1-8; 9 = N.A. Not Applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject act impulsively without appearing to consider the consequences?

Does subject talk to
total strangers as if he/she knew them?
Does subject say things to people that are insensitive or hurt feelings?

Does subject say
crude things or make sexual remarks that they would not usually have said?
Does subject talk openly about very personal or private matters not usually discussed in public?

Does subject take
liberties or touch or hug others in a way that is out of character for him/her?
Does subject show any other signs of loss of control of his/her impulses?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Irritability/Lability
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section J. Aberrant Motor; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions I1-8; 9 = N.A. Not applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject have a bad temper, flying off the handle easily over little things?
Does subject rapidly change moods from one to another, being fine one minute and angry the next?

Does subject have
sudden flashes of anger?
Is subject impatient, having trouble coping with delays or waiting for planned activities?
Is subject cranky and irritable?
Is subject argumentative and difficult to get along with?
Does subject show any other signs of irritability?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Aberrant Motor Behavior
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section K. Sleep; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions 1-8; 9 = N.A. Not applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject pace around the house without apparent purpose?
Does subject rummage around opening and unpacking drawers or closets?
Does subject repeatedly put on and take off clothing?
Does subject have repetitive activities or bad habits that he/she performs over and over?
Does subject engage in repetitive activities such as handling buttons, picking, wrapping string, etc?
Does subject fidget excessively, seem unable to sit still, or bounce his/her feet or tap his/her fingers a lot?
Does subject do any other activities over and over?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Sleep
Notes: 0 = No Proceed to section L. Appetite and e; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquesions 1-9; 9 = N.A. Not applicable

ElementDescription: Does subject have difficulty falling asleep?
Does subject get up during the night (do not count if the patient gets up once or twice per night only to go to the bathroom and falls nack asleep immediately)

Does subject
wander, pace, or get involved in inappropriate activities at night?
Does subject awaken you during the night?
Does subject awaken at night, dress, and plan to go out thinking that it is morning and time to start the day?
Does subject awaken too early in the morning (earlier than was his/her habit)?
Does subject sleep excessively during the day?
Does subject have any other night-time behaviors that bother you that we haven't talked about?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: Appetite and eating disorders
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes Proceed to subquestions 1-9; 9 = N.A. Not applicable

ElementDescription: Has he/she had a loss of appetite?
Has he/she had an increase in appetite?
Has he/she had a loss of weight?
Has he/she gained weight?
Has he/she had a change in eating behavior such as putting too much food in his/her mouth at once?
Has he/she had a change in the kind of food he/she likes such as eating too many sweets or other specific types of food?
Has he/she developed eating behaviors such as eating exactly the same types of food each day or eating the food in exactly the same order?
Have there been any other changes in appetite or eating that I haven't asked about?
Frequency Ratings
Severity Ratings
Caregiver Distress
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = Minimally; 2 = Mildly; 3 = Moderately; 4 = Severely; 5 = Very Severely or extremely

ElementDescription: NPI Total Score
Notes: Calculated by adding the frequency x severity scores of the first 10 domains (A. Delusions � J. Aberrant Motor Behavior) together. Domains K. Night-time Behavior and L. Appetite/Eating Change are not included in the total score. Note if symptoms of a particular domain are absent, the frequency x severity score for that domain would be 0.

ElementDescription: Caregiver Distress Total Score
Notes: Calculated by adding together the scores of the individual NPI caregiver distress questions together for the first 10 domains. Note if symptoms of a particular domain are absent, the caregiver distress score for that domain would be 0.

ElementDescription: Visit name
Numeric Visit Number
Notes: -1.5 = Pre-Screening; -1 = Screening; 0 = Baseline; ## = Visit ## (from 1 to 10); Whole numbers = standard monthly visits; #.001 - #.009 = Unscheduled; #.1 = End of Phase 1; #.2 = End of Phase 2; #.3 = End of Phase 3; #.4 = End of Open Choice Phase; #.5 = End of Study; #.6 = Genetic Analysis; 1000=all visits

ElementDescription: Current Phase. Phase patient was in at the time of the assessment Phase 4 refers to the follow-up phase.
ValueRange: Pre-Rand; Phase 1/1A; Phase 2; Phase 3; Phase 4; Phase 1B; Open-Choice Phase; Screening; Phase 1

ElementDescription: Flag Last Phase 1/1A Visit
Notes: 1=Yes for all records meeting this criteria

ElementDescription: Flag Baseline Phase 1/1A Visit
Notes: 1=Yes for all records meeting this criteria

Does the patient pace, do things over and over such as opening closets or drawers, or repeatedly pick at things or wind string or threads?

Does the patient have difficulty sleeping (do not count as present if the patient simply gets up once or twice per night only to go to the bathroom and falls back asleep immediately)? Is he/she up at night? Does he/she wander at night, get dressed, or disturb your sleep?
Has he/she had any change in appetite, weight, or eating habits (count as NA if the patient is incapacitated and has to be fed)? Has there been any change in type of food he/she prefers?

Is the subject uncooperative, resistive to help from others?
Does the patient seem sad or depressed? Does he/she say that he/she feels sad or depressed?
Is the patient very nervous, worried, or frightened for no apparent reason? Does he/she seem very tense or fidgety? Is the patient afraid to be apart from you?

Does the patient seem too cheerful or too happy for no reason? I don't mean the normal happiness that comes from seeing friends, receiving presents, or spending time with family members. I am asking if the patient has a persistent and abnormally good mood or finds humor where others do not.

Has the patient lost interest in the world around him/her? Has he/she lost interest in doing things or does he/she lack motivation for starting new activities? Is he/she more difficult to engage in conversation or in doing chores? Is the patient apathetic or indifferent?
Does the patient seem to act impulsively without thinking? Does he/she do or say things that are not usually done or said in public? Does he/she do things that are embarassing to you or others?

Does the patient get irritated and easily disturbed? Are his/her moods very changeable? Is he/she abnormally impatient? We do not mean frustration over memory loss or inability to perform usual tasks; we are interested to know if the patient has abnormal irrability, impatience, or rapid emotional changes different from his/her usual self.

Subject Distress Total Score
Notes: Calculated by adding together the scores of the individual NPI distress questions across domains. Note if symptoms of a particular domain are absent, the distress score for that domain would be 0.

ElementDescription: Severity Total Score

ElementDescription: Domain Total Score
Notes: Calculated by adding a 1 for all present domains.
